oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color photograph of a single story white clapboard building, with a low white concrete block ell extending from the back right side. The church has a front gable roof, with an entrance tower on the right side, and concrete block foundation. Four concrete steps lead to a pair of gray paneled doors on the lower level of the tower. Over the entry porch is a shallow, shed roof with a metal eave a few feet above. The tower is topped by a quadrilateral metal roof. The front façade has two double-hung, eight-over-eight light windows. A cement sidewalk leads through the lawn to the entrance.

Mt. Zion AME Church in Centerville, Tennessee is a good example of the small, historic African American churches that still dot the rural landscape in Tennessee. The church has been a vibrant part of the community, hosting both religious services and allowing African American fraternal groups to use the building. In the 1880s, the church started a high school for African Americans. Classes met at the church, and the school was known as the Centreville Male and Female Academy.
